</gallery>'''A/B'''

C/D

'''<big>A</big>''' Normal appearance of the haemorrhoidal mucosa of the anal canal. Internal haemorrhoids do not bulge into the anoscopic lumen.

This is stage I

'''<big>B</big>''' Normal appearance of the haemorrhoidal mucosa of the anal canal. Internal haemorrhoids bulge into the anoscopic lumen.

This is stage II

'''C''' Internal haemorrhoids come out when you push, but then go back into the anal canal.

This is stage III

'''<big>D</big>'''' Internal haemorrhoids are permanently externalized during a pushing effort: they are sometimes the seat of squamous metaplasia (lower part of the photo).

This is stage IV

question.question: Which stage of internal hemorrhoids is characterized by the hemorrhoids coming out when you push but then going back into the anal canal?
question.option_a: Stage I: Internal hemorrhoids do not bulge into the anoscopic lumen.
question.option_b: Stage II: Internal hemorrhoids bulge into the anoscopic lumen.
question.option_c: Stage III: Internal hemorrhoids come out when you push but then go back into the anal canal.
question.option_d: Stage IV: Internal hemorrhoids are permanently externalized during a pushing effort.
